node.title: What caused Hobart's spooky Halloween sunset?
node.alt: Red and orange swirling clouds seen in the sky at sunset.
node.description: Trick or treaters across Hobart on Sunday saw an eerieÂ sight in the evening sky that mirrored the spooky streets below. But the answer to what caused the strange clouds is fairly straightforward.
node.content:
["The skies above Hobart looked just as spooky as the streets below this Halloween, thanks to a combination of perfect light and spectacular cloud formations.", "The incredible mix of bright oranges and deep, dark purples was captured by photographers and trick or treaters out on Sunday night.", "Photographer Wayne Painter in Carlton, east of Hobart, snapped several shots with his camera pointed west, across Tiger Head Bay and towards the city.", "The photos have caused a stir on the Weather Obsessed Facebook group and have so far been shared more than 2,500 times.", "\"It must be Halloween.\"", "", "
The clouds caught a lot of attention on Sunday night due to all the trick or treaters being outdoors at the time.(\u00a0Supplied: Kristy Holzner)
", "Glen Perrin, a forecaster with the Bureau of Meteorology, said the beautiful and haunting layering effect was caused by lenticular clouds.", "\"They're certainly not rare, but the thing that makes the pictures so spectacular is obviously the sun angle at the time, and we're getting all those rich colours within the image,\" Mr Perrin said.", "", "
The clouds formed little waves in the sky.(Supplied: Sue Sullivan)
", "Tasmania's mountainous geography makes it particularly suited to the formation of lenticular clouds.", "\"They tend to form as wind passes over that elevated ground, and it becomes turbulent as it passes over the elevated area,\" Mr Perrin said.", "\"This can produce a wave pattern in the flow [of air].\"", "", "
A could formation seen in Tasmania on Sunday.(Supplied: Jo Jo)
", "Air condenses as it moves towards the crest of the airwave, forming clouds. It then evaporates as it descends the other side, resulting in those telltale half-moon shapes in the sky.", "It is the movement of the air around the cloud formations that gives them that hovering, eerie\u00a0appearance,\u00a0which has sometimes been likened to alien space ships.", "", "
One person spotted a pink and purple heart in the sky.(Supplied: Steve Leeper)
", "For those looking to catch a similar snap, the Bureau of Meteorology says these types of clouds can form at any time of day, at any time of year without prior warning.", "The best thing photographers can do, is simply be prepared.", "\"It's more a case of you have to be ready,\" Mr Perrin said.", "\"Not only clouds, but we've also got auroras in the recent past as well, so you should always be keen and always be ready to take that shot.\""]
